instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.ISL9239: What is ISL9239? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2016-2018 responsible for charging the battery and creating the power rail PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CHGR_BMON: What is CHGR_BMON? CHGR_BMON goes between the ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 that charges the battery & creates PPBUS_G3H and the SMC(system management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip) and provides current sensing information on battery charging to the SMC. If diagnostics reveal an off reading or failure with the charger current sense, this is a good place to start troubleshooting..
definitions.CHGR_AMON: What is CHGR_AMON? CHGR_AMON provides DC current sense information to the SMC(System management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip). It comes from the battery charging chip that controls the laptop charger, battery charging, and creation of PPBUS_G3H(ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip depending on the logic board part number and model). This is used for sensors. If a DC current sense sensor is reading off in diagnostics, this is a place to start looking. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi there. I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. No power. Stuck at 5v and 0A from charger. There was some corrosion around <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s so I replaced with brand new ones (from your store) as well as <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP> (new) and <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>.

PPVIN _G3H is 5V going into <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> but there is no <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> coming from <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP> even after replacing.

Where do I go from here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Post diode mode to ground at L6995 and F7000.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: PS there is no short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
L6995 diode is 1.55V
F7000 is 2.6v and going up

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Did you properly measure in diode mode???
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I apologize. I had my leads reversed:
L6995: 0.376
F7000: 0.445

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> has been replaced again (NEW), as well as another set of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s (NEW) as well as <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> (NEW). 5.19V on the charger pulling 40 milliamps.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 4.25V now. What would be causing this overvoltage? Where should I look next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
So now you get 5V at  <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>?

Corroded resistor on <RESISTOR>R6993</RESISTOR>-97 divider, will change <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage.
<RESISTOR>R6995</RESISTOR>/97 went high, or <RESISTOR>R6993</RESISTOR>/96 decreased values.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 4.63V

<RESISTOR>R6993</RESISTOR> tests good
<RESISTOR>R6995</RESISTOR> good
<RESISTOR>R6996</RESISTOR> good
<RESISTOR>R6997</RESISTOR> good


<SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>: 4.63
<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>: 1.155
VDDA/P: 4.633/4.632
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_L</SIGNAL>: 0.000V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL>: 0.001V
<SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>: 4.246V
<SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL>: 0.005V
<SIGNAL>CHGR_AMON</SIGNAL>: 0.007V

threads.message:
Then change <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>.
It should react when modify the feedback divider.
